bestBHT.bht: The fig tree serves as a parable, its branches and leaves indicating the approaching summer. Just as the fig tree's shoots are broken off for grafting, the multitudes strewed branches for the Lord. The putting forth of leaves and fruit signifies the future revival of the Jewish people, contrasting with the cursed barren fig tree. Examining this natural phenomenon helps us discern the nearing destruction of Jerusalem and the end of the world. Through the Church's afflictions, the Lord prepares his people for the coming immortal glory.

Henry Alford: The English version in ver. 32 is ambiguous, besides being unfaithful.
By 'of' is evidently meant from: but it seems as if it were only concerning.
Learn, 'from the fig-tree the parable': the natural phenomenon which may serve as a key to the meaning.
Albert Barnes: Now learn a parable - See the notes at Matthew 13:3. The word here means, rather, 'an illustration' make a 'comparison,' or judge of this as you do respecting a fig-tree.
Fig-tree - This was spoken on the Mount of Olives, which produced not only olives, but figs. Possibly one was near when he spoke this.

When his branch ... - When the juices return from the roots into the branches, and the buds swell and burst, 'as if tender,' and too feeble to contain the pressing and expanding leaves when you see that, you judge that spring and summer are near.
Marvin Vincent: A parable [την παραβολην] . More strictly, the parable which she has to teach."
Branch [κλαδος] . From klaw, to break. Hence a young slip or shoot, such as is broken off for grafting."
Such were the 'branches' which were cut down and strewed in the Lord 's path by the multitudes (Matthew 21:8).
John Calvin: As the inward sap diffused through the whole tree, after having produced this softness, collects strength to throw itself out for renovating what was dead, so the Lord draws from the corruption of the outward man the perfect restoration of his people.

The general instruction conveyed is, that the weak and frail condition of the Church ought not to lead us to conclude that it is dying, but rather to expect the immortal glory for which the Lord prepares his people by the cross and by afflictions.

For they did not view the kingdom of God in the Gospel as consisting in the peace and joy of faith and in spiritual righteousness, but sought that blessed rest and glory which is concealed under hope till the last day.
Philip Schaff: Putteth forth leaves, or ‘its leaves.’ The blossoms precede the leaves, and when the leaves come, the fruit season is near."
The cursing of the barren fig tree may be in mind even here.
As that, in its judicial unfruitfulness, emblematized the Jewish people, so here the putting forth of the fig tree from its state of winter dryness, symbolizes the future reviviscence of that race.
Archibald T. Robertson: Present active subjunctive according to Westcott and Hort."
John Gill: Take a similitude, or comparison from the fig tree...when its branch is yet tender...and putteth forth leaves; ye know the summer is nigh."
The fig tree putting forth her green figs, is a sign that the winter is past, the spring is come, and summer is at hand.
The putting forth of its branches, leaves, and fruit, fell under the observation of everyone.
John Wesley: Learn a parable — Our Lord having spoke of the signs preceding the two grand events.
Concerning the time of the destruction of Jerusalem, he answers.
Concerning the time of the end of the world, he answers.

bhtAttempts.bht: Just as the fig tree puts forth its tender branches and leaves, signifying the approach of summer, so too should we discern the signs of the times. The illustration of the fig tree, though ambiguous in the English version, serves as a key to understanding the teaching of this parable. The branch of the fig tree is like a young slip, broken off for grafting, just as the multitudes strewed branches before the Lord. The fig tree’s leaves and its subsequent fruitage symbolize the future reviviscence of the Jewish people, contrasting with the barren fig tree cursed by Jesus. By examining the natural phenomenon of the fig tree, we gain insight into the nearness of both the destruction of Jerusalem and the end of the world. Through the hardships and afflictions of the Church, the Lord is preparing his people for the immortal glory that is to come.

By examining this natural phenomenon, we gain insight into the nearness of both the destruction of Jerusalem and the end of the world. Through the hardships and afflictions of the Church, the Lord is preparing his people for the immortal glory to come.

Examining this natural phenomenon helps us discern the nearing destruction of Jerusalem and the end of the world. The fig tree's branches and leaves are like a parable, illustrating the nearness of summer. Just as young shoots are broken off to be grafted, the multitudes strewed branches before the Lord. The putting forth of leaves and fruit symbolizes the future revival of the Jewish people, contrasting with the barren fig tree cursed by Jesus. By examining this natural phenomenon, we gain insight into the approaching destruction of Jerusalem and the end of the world. Through the Church's afflictions, the Lord prepares his people for the coming immortal glory.
